key_points: Congress is considering a fourth round of stimulus checks, while some haven't received previous rounds.
First and second stimulus checks were for $1,200 and $600, third for $1,400.
Ineligibility factors include high income, being claimed as a dependent if over 17, and not filing 2019 or 2020 taxes.
IRS and Social Security Administration urge non-filers to file taxes to ensure receipt of stimulus checks.
Filing 2020 taxes may qualify individuals for 'top-off' payments due to income drops or increased dependents since 2019.
2020 Recovery Rebate Credit available for those who didn't receive full amounts of first two checks.
IRS may not have current address or bank information, leading to undelivered checks.
Changes in address or bank info can be updated through the IRS 'Get My Payment' tool or Form 8822.
IRS won't withhold stimulus checks or 2020 Recovery Rebate Credit for money owed to IRS, but overpayment and certain debts may lead to seized checks.
Newsweek reached out to the IRS for comment with no response before publication.
